title: Signs Your Boss Is A Dick
description: Confirm what you already know about that office nightmare

traits.micromanaging_nightmare: Controls every tiny detail and can't delegate
traits.passive_aggressive_master: Never says what they mean but makes everyone uncomfortable
traits.narcissistic_leader: Everything revolves around them and their ego
traits.blame_shifting_expert: Nothing is ever their fault, masters of finger pointing
traits.guilt_tripping_master: Weaponizes guilt to control and manipulate people
traits.power_tripping_bully: Uses position to intimidate and demean others
traits.two_faced_climber: Sweet to superiors, terrible to subordinates
traits.empty_promise_specialist: Makes promises they never intend to keep
traits.drama_queen_boss: Treats minor issues like catastrophic emergencies
traits.boundary_stomping_maniac: No respect for personal time or space
traits.credit_stealing_parasite: Takes credit for others' work and ideas
traits.reasonable_boss: Actually decent human being trying to do good job

questions.question: You're 10 minutes late because of a car accident. Your boss's reaction?

answers.text: They ask if you're okay and tell you not to worry about it
They lecture you about time management like accidents are planned
They give you the silent treatment for the rest of the day
They make you feel guilty about how your accident inconvenienced them
They publicly call you out in front of everyone as an example

questions.question: You overhear your boss talking trash about you to another manager. Next day they:

answers.text: Act normal because they weren't actually trash talking
Act extra nice to you like nothing happened
Start nitpicking everything you do
Act cold and distant without explanation
Get defensive and blame you for 'eavesdropping'

questions.question: It's 4:58 PM Friday. Your boss dumps a 3-hour project on you saying it's 'urgent.' You:

answers.text: They actually planned ahead so this never happens
Stay late and they disappear immediately
Question the timing and they act personally offended
Try to negotiate and they make you feel guilty about work-life balance
Point out poor planning and they blame you for not anticipating their needs

questions.question: You catch a coworker stealing office supplies. You report it and your boss:

answers.text: Handles it professionally and thanks you for bringing it up
Says they'll handle it but nothing ever happens
Treats you like the problem for being a 'snitch'
Accuses you of not being a team player
Gets angry at you for creating 'drama'

questions.question: The office printer breaks during a major deadline. Your boss:

answers.text: Calmly figures out a solution and keeps everyone focused
Has a complete meltdown like it's the end of civilization
Blames IT even though they warned about the old printer months ago
Micromanages everyone trying to fix it and makes it worse
Disappears and leaves everyone to figure it out

questions.question: You email your boss a detailed project update. Their response:

answers.text: They read it thoroughly and give helpful feedback
They reply 'K' after you spent an hour writing it
They nitpick the font and formatting instead of the content
They forward it to their boss claiming it as their summary
They respond with their own irrelevant story about a similar project

questions.question: Your department wins a company award. Your boss:

answers.text: Makes sure the whole team gets recognized publicly
Accepts the award and barely mentions the team
Acts like their leadership made it possible
Downplays it because they weren't personally involved
Immediately starts planning how to top it next time

questions.question: You request time off for your sister's wedding 6 weeks in advance. Your boss:

answers.text: Approves it immediately and asks you to have fun
Sighs dramatically and mentions how busy that week will be
Approves it but makes passive-aggressive comments about dedication
Acts personally inconvenienced by your family obligations
Questions whether you really need the whole day off

questions.question: During your performance review, your boss:

answers.text: Gives balanced feedback and discusses your career growth
Spends most of the time talking about their own achievements
Brings up every minor mistake from the past year
Makes vague promises about future opportunities
Acts like giving you feedback is a huge personal favor

questions.question: A client calls to compliment your work directly. Your boss:

answers.text: Passes along the compliment and celebrates your success
Takes credit for training you so well
Barely mentions it and changes the subject
Uses it as an opportunity to criticize something else
Warns you not to let it go to your head

questions.question: You accidentally send an email to the wrong person (harmless mistake). Your boss:

answers.text: Laughs it off and reminds you to double-check recipients
Treats it like you just leaked state secrets
Demands a written explanation of what happened
Makes you feel terrible about embarrassing them
Brings it up in meetings for the next month

questions.question: You disagree with your boss in a team meeting. They:

answers.text: Listen to your perspective and discuss it professionally
Shut you down immediately with authority vibes
Get visibly annoyed and defensive
Act hurt like you personally attacked them
Give you the cold shoulder for the rest of the meeting

questions.question: You come in early to finish an important project. Your boss:

answers.text: Appreciates the effort and makes sure you're recognized
Acts like this should be your normal routine
Doesn't acknowledge it at all
Takes credit for motivating you to go above and beyond
Questions why you couldn't finish it during normal hours

questions.question: Your boss promises you a promotion 'soon.' Six months later:

answers.text: You actually get promoted as promised
They act like they never said that
They blame budget constraints they totally knew about
They make you feel ungrateful for bringing it up
They promote someone else and act surprised you're upset

questions.question: You call in sick with the flu. Your boss:

answers.text: Tells you to rest up and get better
Questions whether you're really sick
Makes you feel guilty about the timing
Calls/texts you constantly while you're recovering
Acts inconvenienced by your illness

questions.question: The company has layoffs but your department is safe. Your boss:

answers.text: Communicates clearly about job security and supports affected colleagues
Uses it as leverage to demand more work from everyone
Takes credit for protecting the department
Makes everyone feel guilty for being 'lucky' to keep their jobs
Acts dramatic about the stress they're under

questions.question: You politely decline to work weekend overtime (you have plans). Your boss:

answers.text: Respects your boundaries and finds another solution
Questions your commitment to the team
Acts cold and disappointed without saying why
Makes it clear this will be remembered during reviews
Acts personally hurt by your refusal

questions.question: Your boss makes a mistake that affects the whole team. They:

answers.text: Own up to it immediately and work to fix the problem
Blame everyone except themselves
Act like it never happened
Get defensive when anyone mentions it
Have a meltdown about how stressful everything is

questions.question: Looking honestly at yourself, how would you rate your work performance?

answers.text: I do good work, communicate well, and contribute positively
I'm decent but could probably improve my attitude and effort
I sometimes mess up but it's usually not entirely my fault
I'm excellent and any problems are definitely management's fault
I probably challenge authority too much and can be difficult

questions.question: Your boss gives a presentation about the team's work to senior leadership. They:

answers.text: Give proper credit to team members and highlight everyone's contributions
Make it all about their vision and leadership genius
Present your ideas as if they thought of them
Barely mention the team and focus on company politics
Somehow turn it into a complaint session about team performance

questions.question: You solve a major problem that saves the company thousands of dollars. Your boss:

answers.text: Makes sure upper management knows it was your achievement
Takes full credit for 'developing your problem-solving skills'
Acts like it's no big deal and changes the subject
Questions why the problem existed in the first place
Uses it as an example of what everyone else should be doing

questions.question: You're on vacation and your boss texts you about work. When you don't respond immediately they:

answers.text: Don't text you at all because they respect your time off
Send increasingly urgent messages about non-urgent things
Call you multiple times and act frantic
Make passive-aggressive comments when you return
Act personally hurt that you're not available for them

questions.question: Your boss promises to get you better equipment 'next quarter.' A year later:

answers.text: You actually have the new equipment they promised
They act like they never made that promise
They blame budget issues they totally saw coming
They say 'soon' again and look annoyed you brought it up
They make you feel ungrateful for expecting them to follow through

questions.question: You suggest a process improvement that could save time. Your boss:

answers.text: Listens thoughtfully and helps you implement it
Explains why their way is obviously superior
Takes your idea and presents it as their brainchild
Dismisses it without consideration
Says they'll consider it but never brings it up again

questions.question: You need to leave 30 minutes early for a family emergency. Your boss:

answers.text: Tells you to go and asks if you need anything else
Questions whether it's really an emergency
Sighs and mentions how busy the day is
Acts inconvenienced by your personal crisis
Demands to know exactly what the emergency is

micromanaging_nightmare.title: The Micromanaging Nightmare
micromanaging_nightmare.description: Your boss suffers from terminal control addiction and believes civilization will collapse if they don't personally approve your bathroom breaks.
micromanaging_nightmare.extended:
Your boss has a pathological need to control every microscopic detail of your existence. They hover over your shoulder like a corporate helicopter parent, demand updates every five minutes, and somehow find flaws in work that's objectively perfect. They require approval for decisions that a trained monkey could make independently.

This isn't leadershipâ€”it's professional babysitting with a power complex. They create the exact problems they claim to prevent, then congratulate themselves for catching issues that wouldn't exist if they'd just back off and let you work. Their constant interference turns simple tasks into elaborate approval processes that would make the DMV jealous.

They genuinely believe their suffocating oversight is 'being thorough' when really they're slowly murdering everyone's will to live. They've turned their team into nervous wrecks who second-guess making copies without written authorization. Every email becomes a collaborative effort because heaven forbid you send something without their precious input.

This boss will never change because they mistake controlling everything for being indispensable. They see autonomy as laziness and independence as insubordination. Working for them is like being trapped in a psychological prison where asking to use the bathroom requires a business case and three references.

passive_aggressive_master.title: The Passive-Aggressive Master
passive_aggressive_master.description: Your boss has achieved black belt status in never saying what they actually mean while making everyone feel like garbage.
passive_aggressive_master.extended:
Your boss communicates exclusively through sighs, eye rolls, and sentences that sound innocent but land like psychological warfare. They've weaponized disappointment and turned 'fine' into the most terrifying word in the English language. They agree to your face then sabotage you behind the scenes with the skill of a corporate assassin.

They make promises with zero intention of keeping them, give the silent treatment when upset, and somehow make you feel guilty for things you didn't even do. Their specialty is the backhanded compliment delivered with surgical precision: 'Interesting approach' said with the enthusiasm of someone describing a root canal.

Working for them is like navigating an emotional minefield where everyone becomes amateur therapists, constantly trying to decode their actual feelings and anticipate their mysterious needs. They never engage in direct conflict but somehow make every interaction feel like you're disappointing your grandmother.

This boss has turned their inability to handle confrontation into a weapon of mass psychological destruction. They create an atmosphere where honest communication goes to die and everyone walks around wondering what they did wrong this time.

narcissistic_leader.title: The Narcissistic Leader
narcissistic_leader.description: Your boss genuinely believes they're the main character in everyone's story and that the sun rises and sets on their management prowess.
narcissistic_leader.extended:
Your boss operates under the delusion that they're the office messiah and everyone else exists solely to witness their brilliance. Every team success magically becomes a testament to their visionary leadership, while failures are obviously the result of subordinates failing to properly execute their perfect plans.

They dominate every conversation with tales of their past achievements and somehow make discussions about office supplies about their strategic thinking. They expect applause for basic management tasks and get genuinely confused when people aren't sufficiently grateful for their wisdom and guidance.

Criticism bounces off them like bullets off Superman because they literally cannot compute that they might be wrong about anything. They surround themselves with yes-people and treat independent thinking like a personal attack on their character. Every decision is based on what makes them look good rather than what's actually best for anyone else.

Working for them means your accomplishments get minimized while your mistakes get magnified, especially if those mistakes make them look bad. They've turned the workplace into their personal fan club where genuine feedback is banned and ego-stroking is mandatory.

blame_shifting_expert.title: The Blame-Shifting Expert
blame_shifting_expert.description: Your boss has a PhD in accountability evasion and could dodge responsibility for gravity if things started falling upward.
blame_shifting_expert.extended:
Your boss possesses supernatural abilities when it comes to avoiding blame for literally anything that goes wrong. They're like a corporate magician who can make their responsibility disappear faster than a politician's campaign promises. When projects explode, they immediately transform into investigators determined to prove it's anyone's fault but theirs.

They have selective amnesia about their own decisions and instructions, but somehow remember every minor mistake you made three years ago. That catastrophic idea that destroyed everything? They never suggested it. That impossible deadline they set? You must have misunderstood. That budget approval that made no sense? Finance must have screwed up.

They throw team members under the bus with Olympic-level precision and always emerge from disasters looking like the poor victim of everyone else's incompetence. Their favorite move is turning any criticism into an investigation of your work ethic, competence, or basic understanding of reality.

Working for them means you'll need to document everything like you're preparing for court because any failure will somehow become your fault regardless of actual responsibility. They've created an environment where covering your butt is more important than doing your job.

guilt_tripping_master.title: The Guilt-Tripping Master
guilt_tripping_master.description: Your boss could make Mother Teresa feel guilty for not working harder. They've weaponized guilt to a degree that would impress medieval clergy.
guilt_tripping_master.extended:
Your boss has transformed basic human needs into personal attacks on their well-being. Need a lunch break? They'll mention how they'll have to work through lunch to cover. Want to use earned vacation days? They'll explain how stressful it is to manage without you. Ask for reasonable resources? They'll launch into a speech about budget constraints and how hard they're trying.

They frame every request as a personal burden they must heroically bear, complete with wounded expressions and martyred sighs. They compare your work ethic to others and to their own supposed dedication, making you feel like asking for anything is an act of pure selfishness.

They've mastered the art of making their basic management responsibilities sound like personal favors you should be eternally grateful for. Need training? They're doing you a favor. Want feedback? They're taking time out of their busy schedule. Require basic resources to do your job? They're going above and beyond.

Their guilt trips are so effective that employees find themselves apologizing for things that are completely normal and reasonable. They've turned the workplace into a guilt factory where everyone feels bad for existing.

power_tripping_bully.title: The Power-Tripping Bully
power_tripping_bully.description: Your boss gets genuine satisfaction from wielding power over people who can't fight back. They're basically a playground bully with a business card.
power_tripping_bully.extended:
Your boss discovered that management positions come with the legal right to make people miserable and they've embraced this opportunity with the enthusiasm of a kid in a candy store. They use intimidation, public humiliation, and threats to maintain control because actually leading people requires skills they don't possess.

They get visible satisfaction from watching people squirm under their authority and love making examples of anyone who dares question their decisions. They're sweet as pie to people with more power while treating subordinates like disposable objects that exist solely for their amusement.

They make decisions based on what allows them to flex their authority rather than what makes business sense. They love creating competitive atmospheres where everyone fights for their approval like gladiators in a corporate arena. They use their control over schedules, assignments, and opportunities as weapons to reward loyalty and punish independence.

This boss feeds off the fear and anxiety they create like an emotional vampire. They've turned their management position into a platform for psychological dominance rather than professional leadership. Working for them feels like being trapped in an abusive relationship with someone who holds your paycheck hostage.

two_faced_climber.title: The Two-Faced Climber
two_faced_climber.description: Your boss is basically two different people: a charming angel to superiors and a cold demon to everyone else. They've perfected the art of selective personality disorder.
two_faced_climber.extended:
Your boss should win an Academy Award for their performance as a completely different person depending on who they're talking to. Watch them with senior leadership and you'll see charm, enthusiasm, and eager collaboration. Watch them with direct reports and you'll see dismissiveness, impatience, and barely concealed contempt.

They'll sacrifice subordinates to make themselves look good to upper management without hesitation. They steal ideas and present them upward while simultaneously criticizing the lack of innovation from those below. They're masters of managing up while crushing down with ruthless efficiency.

In meetings with higher-ups, they're collaborative problem-solvers. In meetings with just their team, they're demanding dictators. They save their worst behavior for when there are no witnesses who matter to their career advancement. They understand organizational power structures like a political scientist and exploit them with surgical precision.

This boss views relationships as transactions and career advancement as their primary religion. They've made climbing the corporate ladder their life's mission, with treating people decently as an optional extra that depends entirely on what those people can do for their next promotion.

empty_promise_specialist.title: The Empty Promise Specialist
empty_promise_specialist.description: Your boss has turned promise-making into performance art. They can pledge anything with a straight face while having zero intention of delivering.
empty_promise_specialist.extended:
Your boss promises promotions, raises, better conditions, new equipment, additional staff, and basically whatever people need to hear to stop asking questions and keep working. These promises exist in a permanent state of 'soon' that has the same energy as a software release date.

They have an impressive arsenal of excuses for why nothing has materialized yet: budget freezes, corporate restructuring, timing issues, or the classic 'I'm working on it behind the scenes.' They make people feel ungrateful for expecting them to actually follow through on their commitments.

They use false promises like emotional currency to buy compliance and maintain hope when people are getting frustrated. Need better resources? They'll promise them next quarter. Frustrated with your role? They'll promise a promotion review soon. Overworked? They'll promise to hire help as soon as HR gets their act together.

This boss has discovered that making promises costs nothing and buys significant time and compliance, regardless of their ability or intention to deliver. They've essentially turned hope into a management tool for maintaining the status quo while everyone waits for improvements that will never come.

drama_queen_boss.title: The Drama Queen Boss
drama_queen_boss.description: Your boss reacts to minor workplace hiccups like they're directing a disaster movie. Everything is a crisis worthy of an Emmy nomination.
drama_queen_boss.extended:
Your boss treats normal business challenges with emotional responses that would be excessive for actual emergencies. A delayed email becomes a communication catastrophe. A minor scheduling conflict becomes evidence that the universe is conspiring against them. A small mistake becomes a threat to the company's very existence.

They use words like 'disaster,' 'catastrophe,' and 'nightmare' to describe situations that could be solved with a phone call. They seem genuinely convinced that their theatrical response somehow helps solve problems when really it just creates more stress for everyone else.

They love being the center of attention during any crisis and often seem more invested in processing their feelings about problems than actually fixing them. They expect their emotional state to become everyone's priority and are shocked when people don't share their level of distress about minor issues.

This boss never learned that emotional regulation is a basic job requirement for adults, let alone leaders. They've turned their workplace into their personal therapy session where everyone else has to manage their emotions while trying to get actual work done.

boundary_stomping_maniac.title: The Boundary-Stomping Maniac
boundary_stomping_maniac.description: Your boss treats your personal time, space, and sanity like optional suggestions rather than basic human rights.
boundary_stomping_maniac.extended:
Your boss genuinely cannot understand why you wouldn't want to receive work texts at midnight or discuss quarterly reports during your grandmother's funeral. They view boundaries as obstacles to overcome rather than reasonable limits to respect, and they take any attempt at work-life balance as a personal rejection of their leadership.

They contact you during vacations, schedule 'urgent' meetings during lunch breaks, and somehow always have critical requests right as you're walking out the door. They share inappropriate details about their personal life and expect the same level of uncomfortable oversharing from you.

They feel entitled to know details about your life that have nothing to do with work and get offended when you don't volunteer information. They read over your shoulder, go through your desk, and comment on personal items in your workspace like they're conducting a lifestyle audit.

This boss has never learned that respecting boundaries actually improves relationships and productivity. They mistake invasiveness for caring and boundary-crushing for dedication. Working for them is exhausting because you can never truly disconnect from work or feel safe in your personal space.

credit_stealing_parasite.title: The Credit-Stealing Parasite
credit_stealing_parasite.description: Your boss could steal credit from the inventor of fire and somehow convince everyone they discovered combustion.
credit_stealing_parasite.extended:
Your boss has supernatural abilities when it comes to absorbing credit for work they had nothing to do with. That innovative solution you developed overnight? They'll present it as their strategic vision. That successful project you managed while they were on vacation? They'll explain how their guidance made it possible.

They're masters of revisionist history who gradually edit their role in successes until they become the hero of every story. They use 'we' when taking credit and 'you' when assigning blame with the precision of a legal document. They have selective memory about who actually did the work but somehow always remember their contributions as being massive.

They steal ideas in meetings by rephrasing your suggestions and presenting them like they just had an epiphany. They take your written work, make cosmetic changes, and present it as collaborative effort. They attend your presentations and somehow become co-presenters without contributing any actual content.

This boss has built their entire reputation on other people's work while contributing the leadership equivalent of thoughts and prayers. They're professional parasites who drain recognition from their teams while inflating their own careers through stolen achievements.

reasonable_boss.title: The Reasonable Boss
reasonable_boss.description: Holy cow, plot twist: Your boss might actually be a functional human being who treats people with basic dignity and competence.
reasonable_boss.extended:
After analyzing your responses, it appears your boss might be one of those mythical creatures who understands that management is about supporting people rather than crushing their souls for sport. They provide feedback without destroying self-esteem, handle conflicts without creating more drama, and seem to grasp that employees are humans with lives outside work.

They acknowledge their mistakes instead of blaming everyone else, give credit where it's due instead of stealing it, and don't let their personal emotional disasters become everyone else's problem. They set reasonable expectations, respect boundaries, and understand that leadership requires actual skills rather than just a title and a power complex.

If this assessment is accurate, you've basically won the workplace lottery. Functional bosses are rarer than unicorns in most industries, overshadowed by legions of micromanagers, narcissists, and emotional vampires who somehow convinced someone to give them authority over other humans.

The fact that you took this test suggests you might have concerns, but maybe those are about workplace dynamics in general rather than your specific boss being a psychological nightmare. Consider yourself lucky and use this experience to learn what competent leadership actually looks like, because you might never see it again.
